section.title: Installing the Monitoring Service
section.para: As a prerequisite for installing the Monitoring Service, the OpenStack operator must have installed the OpenStack extensions for CMM.
To install the Monitoring Service, proceed as follows:

listitem.para: Log in to the Control Machine.
The installer uses Ansible group variables for configuration purposes. The group variables are located in the /opt/FJSVsvcmm/group_vars directory.
Open the all_group file with your favorite editor. It defines the main configuration settings.
Example:
Enter the user credentials of a valid OpenStack user in the Monasca Api section. Contact your OpenStack operator for this purpose. He is responsible for creating the required users and roles.

The user you enter must have full access to the Monitoring Service. He must be assigned a role that authorizes him to read and write data. The role must be specified for defaultAuthorizedRoles (see Step 7 below).
Example:
listitem.screen: # Monasca Api CLI - Credentials monasca_user: user: monasca-operator password: "{{ keystone_monasca_operator_user_password }}" project: monasca

listitem.para: Provide the passwords required for installing the Monitoring Service. They are defined in the credentials.yml file that is located in the /opt/FJSVsvcmm directory.
Open the credentials.yml file with your favorite editor.
Example:
Specify the following passwords in the file:
influxdb_mon_api_password for the Monitoring API user accessing the InfluxDB.
influxdb_mon_persister_password for the Persister user accessing the InfluxDB.
database_notification_password for the Notification Engine user accessing the MariaDB database.
database_monapi_password for the Monitoring API user accessing the MariaDB database.
database_thresh_password for the Threshold Engine user accessing the MariaDB database.

keystone_monasca_operator_password for Keystone access of the Monitoring Service operator (see Step 3 above). The user account for the Monitoring Service operator (monasca-operator) is automatically created with the installation.

keystone_admin_password of an OpenStack user account that already exists, for example, admin. This user account is used for creating new user accounts with the installation. It is the user account of the OpenStack operator.

keystone_monasca_agent_password for Keystone access of the user used for configuration purposes of the Metrics and Log Agents on the CMM host. The user account (monasca-agent) is automatically created with the installation.

keystone_admin_agent_password for Keystone access of the user used for configuration purposes of the Metrics and Log Agents on the OpenStack hosts. The user account (admin-agent) is automatically created with the installation.

note.para: The passwords must be handled in a secure way. Access to the credentials.yml is controlled by the Linux file permissions.

listitem.para: To install the CMM components, specific configuration settings are required. They are specified in the group_vars/monasca_group file.

The file contains the default configuration. No changes are required for the individual components. You have to specify only the authorized OpenStack roles (see Step 7 below) and a file system for backing up the Elasticsearch database (see Step 8 below).

note.para: Make changes for the individual components only if you have to deviate from the default.

listitem.para: To view the default configuration, you can open the file with your favorite editor.
Example:
Specify the OpenStack roles that have been authorized by the OpenStack operator in the group_vars/monasca_group file:
defaultAuthorizedRoles specifies the roles which grant the users full access.
agentAuthorizedRoles specifies the roles which grant agent access only. The users' access is restricted to sending monitoring data.
Example:

Specify a file system for backing up the Elasticsearch database in the elasticsearch section of the group_vars/monasca_group file. The file system you specify must later be used for backing up your Elasticsearch database.
Example:
Configure data retention parameters for your InfluxDB database. CMM uses the data retention features offered by InfluxDB.
By default, metrics and alarm history data is automatically deleted from the database if it is older than 60 days. You can change this default, if required.
To change the default, open the group_vars/influxdb_group file with your favorite editor.
Example:
Specify for how long you want to keep the data in the database in the influxdb_retention_policy parameter. The minimum retention period is one hour. Use the following options:
m for minutes
h for hours
d for days
w for weeks
INF for infinite retention
Only single units are supported. This means, for example, that you cannot define a time span of 7230m as 120h 30m.
Example: influxdb_retention_policy: "30d"

Configure data retention parameters for your Elasticsearch database. CMM uses Elasticsearch Curator for managing data retention of Elasticsearch indices. Elasticsearch Curator jobs are automatically run by a Cron daemon, a time-based job scheduler that is driven by a crontab configuration file. The file specifies shell commands for running jobs periodically according to a given schedule.
By default, an Elasticsearch index is automatically deleted if it is older than 60 days. The delete job is executed every day at midnight. You can change these default settings, if required.
To change the default configuration, open the group_vars/elasticsearch_curator_group file with your favorite editor.
Example:
Specify the time span after which you want indices to be removed. It is defined by the deleted_days parameter in the curator_actions section.
Example for a time span of 30 days:
listitem.screen: curator_actions: - { delete_by: age, description: 'Delete indices older than 30 days', deleted_days: 30, disable: False }
listitem.para: The configuration of the Cron daemon is specified in the curator_cron_config section. Use the following parameters for defining when to run the delete job:
minute. Any integer from 0 to 59.
hour. Any integer from 0 to 23 where 0 represents midnight.
day. Any integer from 1 to 31.
weekday. Any integer from 0 to 7 where 0 or 7 represent Sundays.
month. Any integer from 1 to 12.

To provide metrics for log data to system operators, specific configuration settings are required in the group_vars/monasca_log_metrics_group file.

The settings define which log levels are to be evaluated for the log data retrieved by a Log Agent. The example below shows all types of log metrics that are supported by CMM. By default, CMM evaluates warnings and errors.

note.para: To avoid high data loads and a reduced performance, it is recommended that you restrict the types to the default types that are automatically configured by the installer: warning, error, fatal, and critical. Do not use additional types if your focus is on long-term data analysis.

listitem.para: Open the monasca_log_metrics_group file with your favorite editor, and specify the log types to be evaluated.
Example:
Example configuration:
listitem.screen: log_metrics_detect_log_levels: - warning - error - fatal - critical - trace - debug - info

note.para: Additional evaluations for log data can be prepared and configured by the system operator to provide further types of metrics. If you want to customize the Log Metrics component, contact your CMM support for further information.
